values.description: I finally kill the ghost. It was a bug in the Msbuild parser triggered by a non usual combination of characters including a space at the end. [I've reported it upstream](https://issues.jenkins-ci.org/browse/JENKINS-42823), the regexp to fix is too evil in java for me.
values.title: Workaround for the ghost Msbuild warning in Jenkins plugin (->ign-transport3)

summary.raw: I finally kill the ghost. It was a bug in the Msbuild parser triggered by a non usual combination of characters including a space at the end. [I've reported it upstream](https://issues.jenkins-ci.org/browse/JENKINS-42823), the regexp to fix is too evil in java for me.
summary.html: I finally kill the ghost. It was a bug in the Msbuild parser triggered by a non usual combination of characters including a space at the end. I've reported it upstream, the regexp to fix is too evil in java for me.

values.description:
Add CMake option BUILD_TESTING to disable test compilation.
Default value of BUILD_TESTING is ON for backward compatibility.
Added tests target to compile tests when BUILD_TESTING is set to OFF.

This is convenient to compile ign-transport under VS2015, as currently the tests are not compiling under VS2015. Most of the structure has been copied for the equivalent Gazebo PR https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2499/disable-tests-compilation-by-default-new/diff , to avoid to introduce too many differences in the CMake structure of ignition/gazebo projects.
values.title: Add BUILD_TESTING CMake option and tests target

summary.raw:
Add CMake option BUILD_TESTING to disable test compilation.
Default value of BUILD_TESTING is ON for backward compatibility.
Added tests target to compile tests when BUILD_TESTING is set to OFF.

This is convenient to compile ign-transport under VS2015, as currently the tests are not compiling under VS2015. Most of the structure has been copied for the equivalent Gazebo PR https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2499/disable-tests-compilation-by-default-new/diff , to avoid to introduce too many differences in the CMake structure of ignition/gazebo projects.
summary.html:
Add CMake option BUILD_TESTING to disable test compilation. Default value of BUILD_TESTING is ON for backward compatibility. Added tests target to compile tests when BUILD_TESTING is set to OFF.

This is convenient to compile ign-transport under VS2015, as currently the tests are not compiling under VS2015. Most of the structure has been copied for the equivalent Gazebo PR https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2499/disable-tests-compilation-by-default-new/diff , to avoid to introduce too many differences in the CMake structure of ignition/gazebo projects.

values.description:
Remove manual setting of flags for dynamic linking of the Windows CRT library 

The use of `/MDd` for the Debug compilation type and `/MD` for all the other is already ensured by the `Windows-MSVC` CMake Platform [2] file in `NMake Makefiles`, `ninja` and `Visual Studio` generators, 
so those lines should not be necessary. 

Furthermore, on Multi Config CMake Generators such as Visual Studio, the `CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE` variables does not contain the actual configuration with which the code is compiled, that is instead specified by the user at compile time rather than configuration time. This mean that 
the `/MD` flag (linking with the Non-Debug CRT Dynamic Library) is passed even to Debug builds, and this causes linking error with third-party debug dependencies in gazebo . See [2] for a proper way of manipulating config-specific compilation flags for both Single Config and Multiple Config generators. 

[1] https://github.com/Kitware/CMake/blob/6dc7262bf77f551a7f3c36d7ca3023c63ef20af8/Modules/Platform/Windows-MSVC.cmake#L292


[2] https://cmake.org/Wiki/CMake_FAQ#How_can_I_build_my_MSVC_application_with_a_static_runtime.3F
values.title: Remove manual setting of flags for dynamic linking of the Windows CRT library

summary.raw:
Remove manual setting of flags for dynamic linking of the Windows CRT library 

The use of `/MDd` for the Debug compilation type and `/MD` for all the other is already ensured by the `Windows-MSVC` CMake Platform [2] file in `NMake Makefiles`, `ninja` and `Visual Studio` generators, 
so those lines should not be necessary. 

Furthermore, on Multi Config CMake Generators such as Visual Studio, the `CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE` variables does not contain the actual configuration with which the code is compiled, that is instead specified by the user at compile time rather than configuration time. This mean that 
the `/MD` flag (linking with the Non-Debug CRT Dynamic Library) is passed even to Debug builds, and this causes linking error with third-party debug dependencies in gazebo . See [2] for a proper way of manipulating config-specific compilation flags for both Single Config and Multiple Config generators. 

[1] https://github.com/Kitware/CMake/blob/6dc7262bf77f551a7f3c36d7ca3023c63ef20af8/Modules/Platform/Windows-MSVC.cmake#L292


[2] https://cmake.org/Wiki/CMake_FAQ#How_can_I_build_my_MSVC_application_with_a_static_runtime.3F
summary.html:
Remove manual setting of flags for dynamic linking of the Windows CRT library

The use of /MDd for the Debug compilation type and /MD for all the other is already ensured by the Windows-MSVC CMake Platform [2] file in NMake Makefiles, ninja and Visual Studio generators, so those lines should not be necessary.

Furthermore, on Multi Config CMake Generators such as Visual Studio, the CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE variables does not contain the actual configuration with which the code is compiled, that is instead specified by the user at compile time rather than configuration time. This mean that the /MD flag (linking with the Non-Debug CRT Dynamic Library) is passed even to Debug builds, and this causes linking error with third-party debug dependencies in gazebo . See [2] for a proper way of manipulating config-specific compilation flags for both Single Config and Multiple Config generators.

[1] https://github.com/Kitware/CMake/blob/6dc7262bf77f551a7f3c36d7ca3023c63ef20af8/Modules/Platform/Windows-MSVC.cmake#L292

[2] https://cmake.org/Wiki/CMake_FAQ#How_can_I_build_my_MSVC_application_with_a_static_runtime.3F

values.description:
clang analyzer complained about moving the _buffer pointer in Header::Unpack after we are done reading from it.

Header::Pack doesn't have this line, so remove it from Header::Unpack too
values.title: Remove unused statement from Header::Unpack

summary.raw:
clang analyzer complained about moving the _buffer pointer in Header::Unpack after we are done reading from it.

Header::Pack doesn't have this line, so remove it from Header::Unpack too
summary.html:
clang analyzer complained about moving the _buffer pointer in Header::Unpack after we are done reading from it.

Header::Pack doesn't have this line, so remove it from Header::Unpack too

values.description:
I noticed some divergence of our cmake code on our various projects, and did a meld of ign-transport and sdformat and have found these improvements from sdformat to port here:

* only check for SSE on i386 and x86_64

* change logic for skipping -s compiler flag: skip if Clang or MSVC instead of if APPLE

* several whitespace and minor wording changes
values.title: Port cmake fixes from sdformat

summary.raw:
I noticed some divergence of our cmake code on our various projects, and did a meld of ign-transport and sdformat and have found these improvements from sdformat to port here:

* only check for SSE on i386 and x86_64

* change logic for skipping -s compiler flag: skip if Clang or MSVC instead of if APPLE

* several whitespace and minor wording changes
summary.html:
I noticed some divergence of our cmake code on our various projects, and did a meld of ign-transport and sdformat and have found these improvements from sdformat to port here:

  • only check for SSE on i386 and x86_64

  • change logic for skipping -s compiler flag: skip if Clang or MSVC instead of if APPLE

  • several whitespace and minor wording changes

values.description:
This has two small clean-ups in DefaultFlags.cmake:

* There are some lines in an `if (UNIX)` block that are duplicated on lines 43-46, so they are removed.

* Several `CMAKE_*_FLAGS` variables are set in lines 42-46, but the CXX flags aren't included there. Later the CXX flags are set inside a `if (NOT MSVC)` block, but that also adds `-std=c++11`. So I've added an extra line for setting the CXX flags with the other statements so the proper flags will be used in the `MSVC` case.
values.title: Clean up DefaultFlags.cmake

summary.raw:
This has two small clean-ups in DefaultFlags.cmake:

* There are some lines in an `if (UNIX)` block that are duplicated on lines 43-46, so they are removed.

* Several `CMAKE_*_FLAGS` variables are set in lines 42-46, but the CXX flags aren't included there. Later the CXX flags are set inside a `if (NOT MSVC)` block, but that also adds `-std=c++11`. So I've added an extra line for setting the CXX flags with the other statements so the proper flags will be used in the `MSVC` case.
summary.html:
This has two small clean-ups in DefaultFlags.cmake:

  • There are some lines in an if (UNIX) block that are duplicated on lines 43-46, so they are removed.

  • Several CMAKE_*_FLAGS variables are set in lines 42-46, but the CXX flags aren't included there. Later the CXX flags are set inside a if (NOT MSVC) block, but that also adds -std=c++11. So I've added an extra line for setting the CXX flags with the other statements so the proper flags will be used in the MSVC case.

values.description:
There is a [clang warning on el_capitan](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-gazebo8-homebrew-amd64/61/warnings9Result/) that shows up in the gazebo8 build but not in the ign-transport build for some reason. It says:

~~~
moving a local object in a return statement prevents copy elision
~~~

This [stackoverflow post](https://stackoverflow.com/a/9532647) says that it's not necessary to use `std::move` when returning local variables from a function.
values.title: SubscriptionHandler.hh fix std::move compiler warning

summary.raw:
There is a [clang warning on el_capitan](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-gazebo8-homebrew-amd64/61/warnings9Result/) that shows up in the gazebo8 build but not in the ign-transport build for some reason. It says:

~~~
moving a local object in a return statement prevents copy elision
~~~

This [stackoverflow post](https://stackoverflow.com/a/9532647) says that it's not necessary to use `std::move` when returning local variables from a function.
summary.html:
There is a clang warning on el_capitan that shows up in the gazebo8 build but not in the ign-transport build for some reason. It says:

moving a local object in a return statement prevents copy elision

This stackoverflow post says that it's not necessary to use std::move when returning local variables from a function.

values.description:
Clang gives the following warning:

```
/usr/include/ignition/transport3/ignition/transport/SubscriptionHandler.hh:267:16: warning: moving a local object in a return statement prevents copy elision [-Wpessimizing-move]
        return std::move(msgPtr);
               ^
/usr/include/ignition/transport3/ignition/transport/SubscriptionHandler.hh:267:16: note: remove std::move call here
        return std::move(msgPtr);
               ^~~~~~~~~~      ~
```
values.title: Remove std::move for local object in SubscriptionHandler.hh:267

summary.raw:
Clang gives the following warning:

```
/usr/include/ignition/transport3/ignition/transport/SubscriptionHandler.hh:267:16: warning: moving a local object in a return statement prevents copy elision [-Wpessimizing-move]
        return std::move(msgPtr);
               ^
/usr/include/ignition/transport3/ignition/transport/SubscriptionHandler.hh:267:16: note: remove std::move call here
        return std::move(msgPtr);
               ^~~~~~~~~~      ~
```
summary.html:
Clang gives the following warning:

/usr/include/ignition/transport3/ignition/transport/SubscriptionHandler.hh:267:16: warning: moving a local object in a return statement prevents copy elision [-Wpessimizing-move]
        return std::move(msgPtr);
               ^
/usr/include/ignition/transport3/ignition/transport/SubscriptionHandler.hh:267:16: note: remove std::move call here
        return std::move(msgPtr);
               ^~~~~~~~~~      ~

values.description:
This PR adds a `bench` example program that can be used to evaluate the latency and throughput of `ign-transport`.

A deadlock was found in `Node.cc` when using intraprocess communication with a mutex. The modification to `Node.cc` changes intraprocess message delivery from blocking to non-blocking. The behavior now matches interprocess communication. A few tests relied on blocking intraprocess message delivery. Those tests have been modified to use condition variables.

A slight change was made to `NodeShared` to reduce the length of time the mutex is held during message publication. I didn't notice any performance impact, but there might be change with large numbers of publishers and subscribers.

# Dependencies

This PR relies on C++14, and will not be merged until pull request #128 is merged first.

# Benchmarking 

This process could use more automation, but the scope started to get out of hand. Here are the steps to follow:

1. Compile and install as normal.
2. Compile the `examples`
3. Run the `bench` example. In one of the following configurations:

    1. Example intraprocess latency:

            ./bench -l

    2. Example interprocess latency:

            Terminal 1: ./bench -l -r

            Terminal 2: ./bench -l -p

    3. Example intraprocess throughput:

            ./bench -t

    4. Example interprocess throughput:

            Terminal 1: ./bench -t -r

            Terminal 2: ./bench -t -p

4. The `bench` executable with the `-p` option will output data suitable for use with the `latency.gp` and `throughput.gp` gnuplot scripts. Note: you can use the `-o` option with `bench` to output to a file.

5. Produce plots using

    1. Latency

            gnuplot -e "filename='MY_FILENAME'; prefix='MY_PREFIX'" latency.gp

    2. Throughput

            gnuplot -e "filename='MY_FILENAME'; prefix='MY_PREFIX'" throughput.gp

## Results

Raw data is stored in `examples/data`. We can use this (or some other location) to hold a history of benchmark data. All results are the average of 100 iterations. These tests include time required for message serialization and deserialization.

I did not make a test out `bench` because results are highly dependent on hardware, background processes, and network activity.

A few definitions follow.

** Intraprocess**:  Publisher and subscriber in same process.

** Interprocess**: Publisher and subscriber in separate processes on the same PC.

** Wired**: Publisher and subscriber on separate PCs connected via a wired LAN.

**Wireless**: Publisher and subscriber on separate Pcs where one computer was connected to wireless access point and the other hardwired to the LAN.

** Latency**: Latency was measure by publishing a message on `topicA`, and then waiting for a response on `topicB`. The time between publication and reception of the response was divided in half to compute the one-way latency time.

**Throughput**: Throughput was measure by rapidly publishing N messages. Once the N messages have been published, the publisher waits for N responses. The time from start of publication to reception of all N messages is used to compute throughput. 

### Latency

** Intraprocess latency**

I was not expecting this result. My theory as to why the plot is not more constant is a combination of context switches, other processes, etc.

![latency-Intraprocess-all.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/1473127294-latency-Intraprocess-all.png)

![latency-Intraprocess-small.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/3217563991-latency-Intraprocess-small.png)

![latency-Intraprocess-large.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/83318001-latency-Intraprocess-large.png)

**Interprocess latency**

![latency-Interprocess-all.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/2668403778-latency-Interprocess-all.png)

![latency-Interprocess-small.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/3207293959-latency-Interprocess-small.png)

![latency-Interprocess-large.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/556609639-latency-Interprocess-large.png)
**Wired latency**

![latency-Wired-all.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/1861775847-latency-Wired-all.png)

![latency-Wired-small.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/3238222459-latency-Wired-small.png)

![latency-Wired-large.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/2639846742-latency-Wired-large.png)

** Wireless latency**

You may notice that the latency appears better than over the wired network. I believe this is because I ran the wireless tests when no one else was using the network, and the wired test during an active portion of the day.

![latency-Wireless-all.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/177746882-latency-Wireless-all.png)

![latency-Wireless-small.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/4212627213-latency-Wireless-small.png)

![latency-Wireless-large.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/3866951968-latency-Wireless-large.png)

### Throughput

** Intraprocess throughput**

![throughput-Intraprocess-all.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/2829676984-throughput-Intraprocess-all.png)

![throughput-Intraprocess-small.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/3933927565-throughput-Intraprocess-small.png)

![throughput-Intraprocess-large.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/3718225819-throughput-Intraprocess-large.png)

** Interprocess throughput**

![throughput-Interprocess-all.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/3032255927-throughput-Interprocess-all.png)

![throughput-Interprocess-small.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/1568831296-throughput-Interprocess-small.png)

![throughput-Interprocess-large.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/4114343739-throughput-Interprocess-large.png)

** Wired throughput**

![throughput-Wired-all.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/1229007404-throughput-Wired-all.png)

![throughput-Wired-small.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/3679643025-throughput-Wired-small.png)

![throughput-Wired-large.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/3619655927-throughput-Wired-large.png)

** Wireless throughput**

![throughput-Wireless-all.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/365561471-throughput-Wireless-all.png)

![throughput-Wireless-small.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/2412795863-throughput-Wireless-small.png)

![throughput-Wireless-large.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/1670547079-throughput-Wireless-large.png)

## Comparison

I had no idea whether these results were good or bad. [This paper](https://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=2968502) on ROS1 and ROS2 performance can be used as a point of comparison.
values.title: Benchmark

summary.raw:
This PR adds a `bench` example program that can be used to evaluate the latency and throughput of `ign-transport`.

A deadlock was found in `Node.cc` when using intraprocess communication with a mutex. The modification to `Node.cc` changes intraprocess message delivery from blocking to non-blocking. The behavior now matches interprocess communication. A few tests relied on blocking intraprocess message delivery. Those tests have been modified to use condition variables.

A slight change was made to `NodeShared` to reduce the length of time the mutex is held during message publication. I didn't notice any performance impact, but there might be change with large numbers of publishers and subscribers.

# Dependencies

This PR relies on C++14, and will not be merged until pull request #128 is merged first.

# Benchmarking 

This process could use more automation, but the scope started to get out of hand. Here are the steps to follow:

1. Compile and install as normal.
2. Compile the `examples`
3. Run the `bench` example. In one of the following configurations:

    1. Example intraprocess latency:

            ./bench -l

    2. Example interprocess latency:

            Terminal 1: ./bench -l -r

            Terminal 2: ./bench -l -p

    3. Example intraprocess throughput:

            ./bench -t

    4. Example interprocess throughput:

            Terminal 1: ./bench -t -r

            Terminal 2: ./bench -t -p

4. The `bench` executable with the `-p` option will output data suitable for use with the `latency.gp` and `throughput.gp` gnuplot scripts. Note: you can use the `-o` option with `bench` to output to a file.

5. Produce plots using

    1. Latency

            gnuplot -e "filename='MY_FILENAME'; prefix='MY_PREFIX'" latency.gp

    2. Throughput

            gnuplot -e "filename='MY_FILENAME'; prefix='MY_PREFIX'" throughput.gp

## Results

Raw data is stored in `examples/data`. We can use this (or some other location) to hold a history of benchmark data. All results are the average of 100 iterations. These tests include time required for message serialization and deserialization.

I did not make a test out `bench` because results are highly dependent on hardware, background processes, and network activity.

A few definitions follow.

** Intraprocess**:  Publisher and subscriber in same process.

** Interprocess**: Publisher and subscriber in separate processes on the same PC.

** Wired**: Publisher and subscriber on separate PCs connected via a wired LAN.

**Wireless**: Publisher and subscriber on separate Pcs where one computer was connected to wireless access point and the other hardwired to the LAN.

** Latency**: Latency was measure by publishing a message on `topicA`, and then waiting for a response on `topicB`. The time between publication and reception of the response was divided in half to compute the one-way latency time.

**Throughput**: Throughput was measure by rapidly publishing N messages. Once the N messages have been published, the publisher waits for N responses. The time from start of publication to reception of all N messages is used to compute throughput. 

### Latency

** Intraprocess latency**

I was not expecting this result. My theory as to why the plot is not more constant is a combination of context switches, other processes, etc.

![latency-Intraprocess-all.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/1473127294-latency-Intraprocess-all.png)

![latency-Intraprocess-small.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/3217563991-latency-Intraprocess-small.png)

![latency-Intraprocess-large.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/83318001-latency-Intraprocess-large.png)

**Interprocess latency**

![latency-Interprocess-all.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/2668403778-latency-Interprocess-all.png)

![latency-Interprocess-small.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/3207293959-latency-Interprocess-small.png)

![latency-Interprocess-large.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/556609639-latency-Interprocess-large.png)
**Wired latency**

![latency-Wired-all.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/1861775847-latency-Wired-all.png)

![latency-Wired-small.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/3238222459-latency-Wired-small.png)

![latency-Wired-large.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/2639846742-latency-Wired-large.png)

** Wireless latency**

You may notice that the latency appears better than over the wired network. I believe this is because I ran the wireless tests when no one else was using the network, and the wired test during an active portion of the day.

![latency-Wireless-all.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/177746882-latency-Wireless-all.png)

![latency-Wireless-small.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/4212627213-latency-Wireless-small.png)

![latency-Wireless-large.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/3866951968-latency-Wireless-large.png)

### Throughput

** Intraprocess throughput**

![throughput-Intraprocess-all.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/2829676984-throughput-Intraprocess-all.png)

![throughput-Intraprocess-small.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/3933927565-throughput-Intraprocess-small.png)

![throughput-Intraprocess-large.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/3718225819-throughput-Intraprocess-large.png)

** Interprocess throughput**

![throughput-Interprocess-all.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/3032255927-throughput-Interprocess-all.png)

![throughput-Interprocess-small.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/1568831296-throughput-Interprocess-small.png)

![throughput-Interprocess-large.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/4114343739-throughput-Interprocess-large.png)

** Wired throughput**

![throughput-Wired-all.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/1229007404-throughput-Wired-all.png)

![throughput-Wired-small.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/3679643025-throughput-Wired-small.png)

![throughput-Wired-large.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/3619655927-throughput-Wired-large.png)

** Wireless throughput**

![throughput-Wireless-all.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/365561471-throughput-Wireless-all.png)

![throughput-Wireless-small.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/2412795863-throughput-Wireless-small.png)

![throughput-Wireless-large.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/1670547079-throughput-Wireless-large.png)

## Comparison

I had no idea whether these results were good or bad. [This paper](https://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=2968502) on ROS1 and ROS2 performance can be used as a point of comparison.
summary.html:
This PR adds a bench example program that can be used to evaluate the latency and throughput of ign-transport.

A deadlock was found in Node.cc when using intraprocess communication with a mutex. The modification to Node.cc changes intraprocess message delivery from blocking to non-blocking. The behavior now matches interprocess communication. A few tests relied on blocking intraprocess message delivery. Those tests have been modified to use condition variables.

A slight change was made to NodeShared to reduce the length of time the mutex is held during message publication. I didn't notice any performance impact, but there might be change with large numbers of publishers and subscribers.

Dependencies

This PR relies on C++14, and will not be merged until pull request #128 is merged first.

Benchmarking

This process could use more automation, but the scope started to get out of hand. Here are the steps to follow:

  1. Compile and install as normal.
  2. Compile the examples

  3. Run the bench example. In one of the following configurations:

    1. Example intraprocess latency:

      ./bench -l

    2. Example interprocess latency:

      Terminal 1: ./bench -l -r

Terminal 2: ./bench -l -p

    3. Example intraprocess throughput:

      ./bench -t

    4. Example interprocess throughput:

      Terminal 1: ./bench -t -r

Terminal 2: ./bench -t -p

  4. The bench executable with the -p option will output data suitable for use with the latency.gp and throughput.gp gnuplot scripts. Note: you can use the -o option with bench to output to a file.

  5. Produce plots using

    1. Latency

      gnuplot -e "filename='MY_FILENAME'; prefix='MY_PREFIX'" latency.gp

    2. Throughput

      gnuplot -e "filename='MY_FILENAME'; prefix='MY_PREFIX'" throughput.gp

Results

Raw data is stored in examples/data. We can use this (or some other location) to hold a history of benchmark data. All results are the average of 100 iterations. These tests include time required for message serialization and deserialization.

I did not make a test out bench because results are highly dependent on hardware, background processes, and network activity.

A few definitions follow.

Intraprocess: Publisher and subscriber in same process.

Interprocess: Publisher and subscriber in separate processes on the same PC.

Wired: Publisher and subscriber on separate PCs connected via a wired LAN.

Wireless: Publisher and subscriber on separate Pcs where one computer was connected to wireless access point and the other hardwired to the LAN.

Latency: Latency was measure by publishing a message on topicA, and then waiting for a response on topicB. The time between publication and reception of the response was divided in half to compute the one-way latency time.

Throughput: Throughput was measure by rapidly publishing N messages. Once the N messages have been published, the publisher waits for N responses. The time from start of publication to reception of all N messages is used to compute throughput.

Latency

Intraprocess latency

I was not expecting this result. My theory as to why the plot is not more constant is a combination of context switches, other processes, etc.

Interprocess latency

Wired latency

Wireless latency

You may notice that the latency appears better than over the wired network. I believe this is because I ran the wireless tests when no one else was using the network, and the wired test during an active portion of the day.

Throughput

Intraprocess throughput

Interprocess throughput

Wired throughput

Wireless throughput

Comparison

I had no idea whether these results were good or bad. This paper on ROS1 and ROS2 performance can be used as a point of comparison.

values.title: Update the signature of the responser callbacks

summary.html:
This pull request changes the callback signature when advertising a service call. This is the previous signature:

void srvEcho(const ignition::msgs::StringMsg &_req, ignition::msgs::StringMsg &_rep, bool &_result) { ... }

And this is the new one:

bool srvEcho(const ignition::msgs::StringMsg &_req, ignition::msgs::StringMsg &_rep) {...}

The boolean _result parameter was used to flag if the service call succeed or not. To avoid situations in which you forget to set _result, I think is more convenient to use the return value instead. The compiler might help if you forget to return true or false.

values.description:
Note that this pull request only affects publication when there's a subscriber in a separate process.

Previous behavior during a call to `Publish()`:

1. A string is allocated
1. The message is serialized into the previous string
1. The string with the serialized data is **copied** into a `zmq::message_t` and sent
1. ZMQ deallocates the `message_t`
1. We deallocate the string

This is the new behavior:

1. A buffer is allocated
1. The message is serialized into the previous buffer
1. The bufffer with the serialized data is passed into a `zmq::message_t` with a custom deallocation function and sent. Here is where we're saving the copy.
1. ZMQ will call the deallocation function when the message has been sent.
values.title: Use zero copy when publishing messages

Note that this pull request only affects publication when there's a subscriber in a separate process.

Previous behavior during a call to `Publish()`:

1. The message is serialized into the previous string
1. The string with the serialized data is **copied** into a `zmq::message_t` and sent
1. ZMQ deallocates the `message_t`
1. We deallocate the string

This is the new behavior:

1. A buffer is allocated
1. The message is serialized into the previous buffer

summary.html:
Note that this pull request only affects publication when there's a subscriber in a separate process.

Previous behavior during a call to Publish():

  1. A string is allocated
  2. The message is serialized into the previous string
  3. The string with the serialized data is copied into a zmq::message_t and sent
  4. ZMQ deallocates the message_t
  5. We deallocate the string

This is the new behavior:

  1. A buffer is allocated
  2. The message is serialized into the previous buffer
  3. The bufffer with the serialized data is passed into a zmq::message_t with a custom deallocation function and sent. Here is where we're saving the copy.
  4. ZMQ will call the deallocation function when the message has been sent.

values.description:
Since ign-transport has fallback logic from ign-msgs1 to ign-msgs0,
we have to use the correct one when generating pkg-config and
cmake files for other projects.  Do that here.
values.title: Use the correct version of ign-msgs when generating pkg-config and cmake files.

cmake files for other projects.  Do that here.

values.description:
The `default` branch, which is supposedly ahead of `ign-transport4`, currently supports either ign-msgs 0 or 1, but `ign-transport4` only supports `ign-msgs1`.

We should either let `ign-transport4` also accept 0, or remove 0 from default. This PR implements the first option.
values.title: Backport pull request #230 to ign-transport4

summary.raw:
The `default` branch, which is supposedly ahead of `ign-transport4`, currently supports either ign-msgs 0 or 1, but `ign-transport4` only supports `ign-msgs1`.

We should either let `ign-transport4` also accept 0, or remove 0 from default. This PR implements the first option.
summary.html:
The default branch, which is supposedly ahead of ign-transport4, currently supports either ign-msgs 0 or 1, but ign-transport4 only supports ign-msgs1.

We should either let ign-transport4 also accept 0, or remove 0 from default. This PR implements the first option.

values.reason: It's simpler to support only one version

values.description:

I also merged ign-transport 4 into default but it doesn't bring anything new.

This adds basic authentication. The scope is limited to enabling authentication on a whole process. Fine-grained control can come in the future.

I need to create a tutorial for this, and a few issues to capture future work.

values.description:
This is the initial proposal for the with the following changes:

* Removed the `connections` table
    * Even if record tool could know the  `AdvertiserOptions`, a user may want to playback with different options. How about handling this in playback's CLI/API instead?
* Allow `message_types.proto_descriptor` to be `NULL`
    * Allows recording when the proto file is not available to the record tool
* Add an index on `messages.time_recv_utc`
    * Doesn't change any queries, just speeds them up. This isn't a change as much as something implied by the proposal but not explicitly stated.

The intent of this file is to be used by the record tool to create a brand new database.

For testing purposes, a database can be initialized on the command line using `sqlite3 path/to/new/file < 0.1.0.sql`.
values.title: Record schema 0.1.0

    * Allows recording when the proto file is not available to the record tool
* Add an index on `messages.time_recv_utc`
    * Doesn't change any queries, just speeds them up. This isn't a change as much as something implied by the proposal but not explicitly stated.

summary.html:
This is the initial proposal for the with the following changes:

  • Removed the connections table
    • Even if record tool could know the AdvertiserOptions, a user may want to playback with different options. How about handling this in playback's CLI/API instead?
  • Allow message_types.proto_descriptor to be NULL
    • Allows recording when the proto file is not available to the record tool
  • Add an index on messages.time_recv_utc
    • Doesn't change any queries, just speeds them up. This isn't a change as much as something implied by the proposal but not explicitly stated.

The intent of this file is to be used by the record tool to create a brand new database.

For testing purposes, a database can be initialized on the command line using sqlite3 path/to/new/file < 0.1.0.sql.

values.description:
This code is not intended to be merged. I'm opening it for discussion.

It is a working proof of concept of recording all ignition transport topics using the schema from pull request #244. The only missing piece of this is getting the message name and proto file. Right now this records the message type name as `.unknown.message.Type`.

@caguero The node has an api for getting the names of topics. How does one get the message type for that topic?


```
cmake -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Debug  -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=path/to/install path/to/src/ign-transport/tools/record/
make && make install
./install/bin/talker &
rm -f /tmp/test.db && ./install/bin/record /tmp/test.db
```
values.title: Record proof of concept (do not merge)

values.description:
This pull request adds the message type name and topic partition to the `MessageInfo` class. This info previously was not be available to a subscriber using the generic protobuf message interface.

@caguero This strips the leading `@/` and trailing `@` from the partition before putting it into the info class. Where did the leading `/` come from? Is it important?

values.description:
This PR sets the file structure for logging code. It is meant to be compatible with the soon-to-be components feature of ignition-cmake. Nothing interesting happens in the files added; they're present to allow committing the folder structure.

Once this PR is merged I'll change the location of the schema file in pull request #244 to be somewhere in this new folder.

values.description:
This PR is a work-in-progress, but is mostly complete. I'm opening it to facilitate discussion on the concept and to check whether this is an avenue that we want to take.

The key features of this PR are the abilities to publish and subscribe to arbitrary raw message data, while only performing serialization or deserialization when it is absolutely necessary.

This probably sounds like it's merely a performance improvement, but it's actually far more important than that: This allows us to subscribe to *any* type of message, including messages whose protobuf descriptors are not available to us (e.g. custom user-defined messages). This feature is necessary for logging in order for us to record custom messages which were generated outside of `ign-msgs`. Protobuf will always fail to deserialize a message whose type was generated in a library that is not linked to the current application, so this PR allows us to skip the deserialization step and send the message data directly into the logger.

The key implementation detail in this PR is that I've introduced a new type of subscription handler: `RawSubscriptionHandler`. This new subscription handler is managed independently of the existing `ISubscriptionHandler`.

TODO List:

1. Create tests for the raw publisher and subscriber functions

2. Create an unsubscribe function for raw subscriptions

This PR may result in some backlash (for reasons that I'll enumerate below), so I'm completely open to  discussing and reversing the things that I'm proposing in this PR. Here's a list of what I suspect may be controversial:

1. There's a significant refactoring of `Node::Publisher::Publish(~)` and `NodeShared::RecvMsgUpdate()`. My goal in the refactoring was to keep the changes as DRY as possible. In particular, publishing a raw message to local subscribers is extremely similar to receiving a message from remote publishers and passing it along to your node's local subscribers. Therefore, most of the functionality of `NodeShared::RecvMsgUpdate()` has been refactored into `NodeShared::CheckHandlerInfo(~)` and `NodeShared::TriggerSubscriberCallbacks(~)`.

2. Generally we want to discourage end-users from doing anything with raw messages, but we want the API for it to be publicly exposed for our own use, and perhaps for advanced users to take advantage of. Therefore, I've introduced an `Advanced` API design pattern: To publish a raw message, you call `publisher->UseAdvancedFeatures().RawPublish(...)`. To create a raw subscription, you would call `node->UseAdvancedFeatures().RawSubscribe(...)`. Since these features are hidden behind the `UseAdvancedFeatures()` functions, it's painfully obvious that these are advanced features which are only meant for advanced users. If we don't like this design pattern, I can easily move `RawPublish` and `RawSubscribe` into the normal API and get rid of the `Advanced` classes.

3. In the definition of [RawSubscriptionHandler](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/src/af616bbfe39865c1ce4ab70556f6478389c68240/include/ignition/transport/SubscriptionHandler.hh?at=RawPublishSubscribe&fileviewer=file-view-default#SubscriptionHandler.hh-329) I'm introducing a pimpl design pattern which is a bit stylistically different than what we've been using so far. Instead of creating a `PrivateXXX` class, we create a `XXX::Implementation` class and name its instance `pimpl`. This pattern is a popular one among pimpl users because it allows us to avoid polluting namespaces with classes that can't be accessed by users. It creates a cleaner code model, which is really nice for users who use autocomplete. I don't know if our `PrivateXXX` and `dataPtr` pattern is considered finalized in our style guide or if we've just been using it to be consistent, but I wanted to throw this suggestion out there to see what people think. I can easily switch it over to `PrivateXXX` and `dataPtr` if we would rather remain consistent.
values.title: [WIP] Subscribe and publish raw (serialized) data

summary.raw:
This PR is a work-in-progress, but is mostly complete. I'm opening it to facilitate discussion on the concept and to check whether this is an avenue that we want to take.

The key features of this PR are the abilities to publish and subscribe to arbitrary raw message data, while only performing serialization or deserialization when it is absolutely necessary.

This probably sounds like it's merely a performance improvement, but it's actually far more important than that: This allows us to subscribe to *any* type of message, including messages whose protobuf descriptors are not available to us (e.g. custom user-defined messages). This feature is necessary for logging in order for us to record custom messages which were generated outside of `ign-msgs`. Protobuf will always fail to deserialize a message whose type was generated in a library that is not linked to the current application, so this PR allows us to skip the deserialization step and send the message data directly into the logger.

The key implementation detail in this PR is that I've introduced a new type of subscription handler: `RawSubscriptionHandler`. This new subscription handler is managed independently of the existing `ISubscriptionHandler`.

TODO List:

1. Create tests for the raw publisher and subscriber functions

2. Create an unsubscribe function for raw subscriptions

This PR may result in some backlash (for reasons that I'll enumerate below), so I'm completely open to  discussing and reversing the things that I'm proposing in this PR. Here's a list of what I suspect may be controversial:

1. There's a significant refactoring of `Node::Publisher::Publish(~)` and `NodeShared::RecvMsgUpdate()`. My goal in the refactoring was to keep the changes as DRY as possible. In particular, publishing a raw message to local subscribers is extremely similar to receiving a message from remote publishers and passing it along to your node's local subscribers. Therefore, most of the functionality of `NodeShared::RecvMsgUpdate()` has been refactored into `NodeShared::CheckHandlerInfo(~)` and `NodeShared::TriggerSubscriberCallbacks(~)`.

2. Generally we want to discourage end-users from doing anything with raw messages, but we want the API for it to be publicly exposed for our own use, and perhaps for advanced users to take advantage of. Therefore, I've introduced an `Advanced` API design pattern: To publish a raw message, you call `publisher->UseAdvancedFeatures().RawPublish(...)`. To create a raw subscription, you would call `node->UseAdvancedFeatures().RawSubscribe(...)`. Since these features are hidden behind the `UseAdvancedFeatures()` functions, it's painfully obvious that these are advanced features which are only meant for advanced users. If we don't like this design pattern, I can easily move `RawPublish` and `RawSubscribe` into the normal API and get rid of the `Advanced` classes.

3. In the definition of [RawSubscriptionHandler](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/src/af616bbfe39865c1ce4ab70556f6478389c68240/include/ignition/transport/SubscriptionHandler.hh?at=RawPublishSubscribe&fileviewer=file-view-default#SubscriptionHandler.hh-329) I'm introducing a pimpl design pattern which is a bit stylistically different than what we've been using so far. Instead of creating a `PrivateXXX` class, we create a `XXX::Implementation` class and name its instance `pimpl`. This pattern is a popular one among pimpl users because it allows us to avoid polluting namespaces with classes that can't be accessed by users. It creates a cleaner code model, which is really nice for users who use autocomplete. I don't know if our `PrivateXXX` and `dataPtr` pattern is considered finalized in our style guide or if we've just been using it to be consistent, but I wanted to throw this suggestion out there to see what people think. I can easily switch it over to `PrivateXXX` and `dataPtr` if we would rather remain consistent.
summary.html:
This PR is a work-in-progress, but is mostly complete. I'm opening it to facilitate discussion on the concept and to check whether this is an avenue that we want to take.

The key features of this PR are the abilities to publish and subscribe to arbitrary raw message data, while only performing serialization or deserialization when it is absolutely necessary.

This probably sounds like it's merely a performance improvement, but it's actually far more important than that: This allows us to subscribe to any type of message, including messages whose protobuf descriptors are not available to us (e.g. custom user-defined messages). This feature is necessary for logging in order for us to record custom messages which were generated outside of ign-msgs. Protobuf will always fail to deserialize a message whose type was generated in a library that is not linked to the current application, so this PR allows us to skip the deserialization step and send the message data directly into the logger.

The key implementation detail in this PR is that I've introduced a new type of subscription handler: RawSubscriptionHandler. This new subscription handler is managed independently of the existing ISubscriptionHandler.

TODO List:

  1. Create tests for the raw publisher and subscriber functions

  2. Create an unsubscribe function for raw subscriptions

This PR may result in some backlash (for reasons that I'll enumerate below), so I'm completely open to discussing and reversing the things that I'm proposing in this PR. Here's a list of what I suspect may be controversial:

  1. There's a significant refactoring of Node::Publisher::Publish(~) and NodeShared::RecvMsgUpdate(). My goal in the refactoring was to keep the changes as DRY as possible. In particular, publishing a raw message to local subscribers is extremely similar to receiving a message from remote publishers and passing it along to your node's local subscribers. Therefore, most of the functionality of NodeShared::RecvMsgUpdate() has been refactored into NodeShared::CheckHandlerInfo(~) and NodeShared::TriggerSubscriberCallbacks(~).

  2. Generally we want to discourage end-users from doing anything with raw messages, but we want the API for it to be publicly exposed for our own use, and perhaps for advanced users to take advantage of. Therefore, I've introduced an Advanced API design pattern: To publish a raw message, you call publisher->UseAdvancedFeatures().RawPublish(...). To create a raw subscription, you would call node->UseAdvancedFeatures().RawSubscribe(...). Since these features are hidden behind the UseAdvancedFeatures() functions, it's painfully obvious that these are advanced features which are only meant for advanced users. If we don't like this design pattern, I can easily move RawPublish and RawSubscribe into the normal API and get rid of the Advanced classes.

  3. In the definition of RawSubscriptionHandler I'm introducing a pimpl design pattern which is a bit stylistically different than what we've been using so far. Instead of creating a PrivateXXX class, we create a XXX::Implementation class and name its instance pimpl. This pattern is a popular one among pimpl users because it allows us to avoid polluting namespaces with classes that can't be accessed by users. It creates a cleaner code model, which is really nice for users who use autocomplete. I don't know if our PrivateXXX and dataPtr pattern is considered finalized in our style guide or if we've just been using it to be consistent, but I wanted to throw this suggestion out there to see what people think. I can easily switch it over to PrivateXXX and dataPtr if we would rather remain consistent.
